title: In California, if you voluntarily return your car, can your income be garnished?
question: I'm a retired vet with a non-service connected disability pension and retirement income. The auto loan has become a personal and financial hardship, so if I just take it back to the car company, will my income be garnished?
answers: The vehicle will be sold at auction and the proceeds applied to the balance. Before surrendering the vehicle may I suggest obtaining a free consultation with local counsel to evaluate your options.

Your question does require consideration of your military benfits and retirement income. I believe what ypu are geting at is whether your pension-type benefits are reachable by judgment creditors, or if such income is protected under the law, similar to protections afforded child support payments, etc.

First, Always negotiate with your creditors. Most creditors are willing to negotiate rather than incur the cost of repossessing a vehicle and hiring an attorney to obtain a debt judgment, especially if doing so would throw you into bankruptcy.

I believe a bankruptcy attorney could provide you with a better answer. I will change you question to the debt category.

Without more facts, like the car sucks, they screwed up on the contract disclosures or they lied to you about the car itself in the sale, just bringing it back is called a voluntary repo. This could damage your credit AND if there is an outstanding balance after the repo and there almost always is, you can end up in the deep end of the pool for a long time, without a floatation device. Best military/car fraud attorneys in your immediate area are Rosner, Barry, Babbit, IMHO and if there is any way to help, they can do it. Good luck with it.

In all likelihood, just taking it back is not the best way to go. I agree with Ms. Straus's suggestion. And if the car happens to be worth more than it would take to pay off the loan or only a little bit less, another idea is to sell it and pay off the loan, or if less, maybe negotiate that they would take what you get in full settlement. They may or may not be willing to do that if you explain your circumstances.

Not immediately--and, if you call and talk to the lender, you may be able to work out a deal. A refi, or a payment plan for the balance. (The vehicle is likely not worth the loan balance. )

An attorney might be able to assist you on a limited scope representation basis.

I agree with my colleague. More information is needed to determine the answer to your question. An attorney would need to actually look at the contract in order to explain the possibilities to you. I recommend you consult with an attorney in your area. Avvo has a search tool for you to find an attorney.
This has nothing to do with military law or your prior service, or veteran status and everything to do with contract law.
